column4: Hey guys, I want to download some packages after my roomie steps out in about 3 hours.  How do I do that?  Do I have to set up a cron job or something?
basically I want to run 'sudo apt-get install xchat' at a certain time
for one-time things like this, you can use 'at'
sudo at now+3hour, then type your command, enter, ctrl-d.
it won't run it in your shell, it'll just run it.
after you add something, you can see it with 'atq'  (or sudo atq if you've added it to root's queue)
gedit won't work.  It's not connected to 'you' at all.
You can't do anything that interacts with the user.  Because it doesn't know which xserver to connect to, or which tty, etc, etc.
that'll work.  Although I'd give both commands an absolute path.
I have this long line of packages I want to install on my new ubuntu machine.  I've used this line of apt a lot before
No, no, what are you doing with at?
What exactly are you doing (with your test case) to enter the line into at?
That command works fine here to adding it to the at queue.
Unless you feel like coming home to a broken system tomorrow.
If you have to force it to yes, it's asking if you really want to do something you shouldn't.
